title: Nutrition and Food Science - Dietetics Concentration (MS) Virtual Information Session
description:
Become a registered dietitian  
 Our new  Dietetics Concentration in the Masters of Nutrition and Food Science   is   ACEND-accredited as a Graduate Program (GP). Students will earn their MS and be eligible to sit for the Registration Exam for Dietitians. 
 Highlights: 
 
 Full-time, 2-year program (42 credits) 
 In-person classes and supervised experiential learning placements located throughout New Jersey 
 All placements coordinated by program faculty 
 Program prepares students to take the RDN exam 
 
 Join us for a virtual information session January 6 at 7:00 PM (EST)  to get clarity on what’s next and how we can help you get there.

title: Alternate Route Certification Virtual Information Session
description:
Looking to start your teaching career in New Jersey? Our  Alternate Route Teacher Certification Programs  offer a flexible and structured pathway to becoming a certified educator while working full-time. Whether you’re looking to teach Preschool through Grade 3 (P-3), Elementary Education (K-6), or a specific subject area at the P-12 level, our programs are designed to support career changers and aspiring teachers who already hold a Certificate of Eligibility (CE). With coursework focused on instructional planning, classroom management, and student development, you’ll gain the essential skills needed to excel in today’s classrooms. Our faculty and dedicated support system ensure that you receive high-quality preparation while fulfilling New Jersey’s certification requirements. 
 Join us for our upcoming  virtual information session on January 7 at 4:00 PM (EST) , where we’ll cover all three certification programs, walk you through the application process, and provide insights on coursework and program expectations.

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Clarinet Day with Ricardo Morales
description:
Cali School of Music’s Clarinet Day 2026!   
 Montclair State University’s John J. Cali School of Music  invites you and your clarinet students to our Eighth Annual Clarinet Day to be held Sunday, January 18, 2026, starting 9:30 AM in Chapin Hall (home of the Cali School of Music) on the Montclair State University campus.   
 This inspirational all-day event will feature distinguished Cali School of Music clarinet faculty members  Benjamin Baron, Keriann DiBari  and  David Sapadin  along with our very special guest artist  Ricardo Morales,  principal clarinetist of the  Philadelphia Orchestra.   
 There will be a masterclass and performance by Ricardo Morales, insightful and motivational presentations by Cali School clarinet faculty, a clarinet choir for all participants to join, as well as vendors and repair services.   
 A light lunch will also be provided.  We invite you and your clarinet students to join us on this special day and celebrate all things clarinet!   
 This event is Free.  Registration is Required.  
 REGISTER HERE 
 Registration + Admin Questions: Dr. Marla Meissner, Recruitment + Student Visit Coordinator, Cali School of Music Email:  meissnerm@montclair.edu

title: Audiology (AuD) Virtual Information Session
description:
Take your research to the next level Our  Audiology program  is designed to empower you to excel in multiple roles—clinician, educator, administrator, and researcher. 
 
 As a clinician, you'll be able to identify the hearing health needs of individuals and design, implement and evaluate treatment plans to meet those needs.  
 In education, you'll be equipped to share your knowledge and inspire others in community healthcare settings. 
 As an administrator, you'll learn to lead, innovate, and elevate audiology services across diverse environments. 
 And with a strong foundation in research, you'll be ready to explore new frontiers in audiology, applying cutting-edge insights directly to your practice. 
 
 Join us for a virtual information session January 20 at 7:00 PM (EST)  to become a versatile leader in the dynamic field of audiology, where your impact can resonate for a lifetime.

title: Graduate Mathematics Programs Virtual Information Session
description:
Enhance your Mathematics knowledge with Montclair's graduate programs! 
 The Department of Mathematics at Montclair State University offers multiple graduate programs in Mathematics: 
   
 
 Mathematics Education (MA) Online - Fully Online (synchronous) - 11 Courses to complete - Intended for future and current teachers interested in enhancing their understanding of K12 mathematics and related teaching practices. 
 
   
 
 Teaching Middle Grades Mathematics Certificate Online Program - Fully Online (synchronous) - 5 Courses (counts toward MA above) - Designed for current or future middle grades mathematics teachers, including current teachers in related disciplines (e.g., science, business, computer science) as well as in other disciplines, who are teaching, preparing to teach, or are interested in teaching mathematics in the middle grades. 
 
   
 
 MS in Mathematics, Mathematics Education Concentration - In-Person and Online Courses - 11-12 Courses to complete  - Intended for students who are currently teachers interested in enhancing their content knowledge, exploring current research-based pedagogies, or considering doctoral studies in mathematics education (we also offer a  Mathematics Education PhD program !)    
 Elementary School Certification with Subject Matter Specialization: Mathematics in Grades 5-8 Online Program -  Online courses - 5 courses  - Additional teacher certification program for candidates who already hold an appropriate New Jersey CEAS or Standard Certification in another content area. This additional certification entitles the candidate to teach mathematics in Grades 5-8 in all New Jersey public schools. 
 
 Registration is LIVE for our Graduate Mathematics Programs Virtual Information Session January 24 at 11:00 AM (EST) . If you're interested in understanding math on a deeper level, wish to learn new teaching strategies for your students, and grow as a professional, our information session is the perfect place to connect directly with the faculty in the department.

title: Free Swim Lessons *Beginner*
description:
Brief Description:  
 Never swam before? No problem! These lessons will give you the important foundational skills in swimming and help you be more comfortable in the pool. Learn how to use proper breath control, float, and swim with a kickboard.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Being comfortable in the water 
 Learning how to float on your back and front 
 Learning how to kick off the wall with a kickboard 
 Introducing proper breath control in the water 
 Learning how to tread water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Froggy Kick) 
 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where?

 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: French Horn College Audition Preparation Masterclass
description:
College Audition Preparation Masterclass for  French Horn  
 Calling all high school French horn players! 
 Getting ready for college auditions? Join us for a  FREE College Audition Preparation French Horn Masterclass  at the John J. Cali School of Music  
 French Horn College Audition Preparation Masterclass 
 With Professors  Sara Cyrus  and  Kyle Hoyt 
 Mon | Jan 26, 2026 5–8 PM Leshowitz Recital Hall, Chapin Hall, Cali School of Music Montclair State University 
 Led by Cali School of Music faculty  Kyle Hoyt  and  Sara Cyrus , this masterclass features live audition performances by high school students, expert feedback, and practical tips to help you bring your  best  to every audition. Audience members are welcome to observe, learn, and ask questions throughout the event.

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: Higher Education (MA) Virtual Information Session
description:
Build your career in Higher Education    
 Whether you're already working in  higher ed  or looking to break into the field, our flexible program is designed to meet you where you are - and help you go even further. 
 We're hosting a  virtual information session on January 29  at 6:00 PM . This is a no-pressure, exploratory space to meet our team and determine if our program fits your goals. 
 Our coursework offers a broad focus on administration and leadership, preparing students for a variety of roles in higher education. The curriculum integrates organizational and social science perspectives and explores key administrative and programmatic issues.

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Montclair State Mainstage Opera "DIE ZAUBERFLÖTE"
description:
Montclair State  Mainstage Opera & University  Symphony Orchestra  
   
 presents 
 DIE ZAUBERFLÖTE 
 Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart,  Composer 
 Emanuel Schikaneder,  Librettist 
 Janine Morita Colletti, Director Kyle Ritenauer, Conductor 
 Valentina Cannao,  Scenic & Costume Design 
 David Orlando,   Lighting Design 
 Lili Federico,  Multimedia/Projection Design 
 Maxine Steinman,  Choreographer 
 Paige Elise Buchanan Stewart,  Livestream Production 
   
 Alexander Kasser Theater 
 Saturday, January 31 @ 8:00 PM  Tickets Sunday, February 1 @ 3:00 PM  Tickets   
   
 
 
 A dragon to be vanquished. A magic flute that conquers hearts. A queen whose rage blazes among the stars. A secretive order holding the power of the sun. 
 
 
 One of the most beloved operas of all time, Mozart’s  Die Zauberflöte  ( The Magic Flute ) is a dazzling adventure where fairy tale, comedy, and timeless wisdom meet.  With music that soars from the hilarious to the sublime, it enchants audiences of all ages. 
 Follow Prince Tamino and Princess Pamina as they brave trials of fire, water, and silence in their search for love and enlightenment. Laugh with the irrepressible bird-catcher Papageno, and be swept away by the Queen of the Night’s blazing vengeance and show-stopping arias. Beneath its fantastical surface lies a story of courage, compassion, and the triumph of harmony over darkness. 
 Join us for an unforgettable journey of magic, music, and imagination. 
 Sung in German • Spoken dialogue in English (Janine Morita Colletti)

title: Educational Leadership (MA) – Fast Track Virtual Information Session
description:
Accelerate your path to leadership 
 Our  Fast Track option  for the Educational Leadership (MA) allows students to earn a 36-credit degree and principal and supervisor certification in 14 months while working full-time. This program is completed within a one-year time frame, from summer to summer. 
 New cohorts for the Fast Track Option begin each Summer. Interested applicants should  complete their application for admission by April 1   each year. Join us for a webinar on February 7 at 10:00 AM (EST)   to learn how this fast-track option can propel aspiring leaders and administrators toward their goals.

title: Magnificent Bird / Book of Travelers | Two Song Cycles written and performed by Gabriel Kahane
description:
Experience two distinct works by acclaimed songwriter and performer Gabriel Kahane in one unforgettable day.  
   
 In this duo of intimate solo musical plays, composer Gabriel Kahane blends songwriting and storytelling for a singular, poignant theatrical event. Book of Travelers recounts the strangers he met on a 9,000-mile train journey through a divided America, and Magnificent Bird chronicles a year he spent entirely off-line, and the unexpected turbulence of living quietly. Performed on alternating nights, these two concept albums offer a relentless self-inquiry, and a searing portrait of a world in flux.  To join us, be sure to pick up your free student ticket from the Alexander Kasser Theatre box office or our mobile box office in the student center lobby, Tuesday - Thursday, 11:30 AM to 2:00 PM, and show your student ID at the PEAK desk in the lobby when you arrive for a surprise gift from PEAK. 
   
 Hailed as “one of the finest songwriters of the day” by The New Yorker, Gabriel Kahane is a musician and storyteller whose work spans the theater, club, and concert hall. Highlights of the 2024-25 season include a return to the New York stage in a production at Playwrights Horizons, performances at the Philharmonie de Paris, Wigmore Hall, and the Concertgebouw with fellow composer/performer Caroline Shaw, the premiere of a clarinet concerto for Anthony McGill, a solo debut with the Orchestre National de Lyon, and Kahane’s San Francisco conducting debut in Carla Kihlstedt’s Twenty-six Little Deaths. Kahane's collaborators range from Phoebe Bridgers, Paul Simon, Sufjan Stevens, and Sylvan Esso, to the Danish String Quartet, Roomful of Teeth, and Attacca Quartet. As a writer, he has been published by The New Yorker online and The New York Times; a newsletter and collection of essays on music, literature, and politics can be found at  gabrielkahane.substack.com . 
   
 4:00 pm Magnificent Bird 
 Run Time:  74 minutes, no intermission. 
   
 Magnificent Bird, is an intimate reflection on a year of self-imposed isolation during which the artist set out to write a song every day. With contributions from Andrew Bird, Chris Thile, Amelia Meath (Sylvan Esso), and Pulitzer Prize- winning composer Caroline Shaw, this collection explores the delicate balance between personal introspection and global crises. It’s a vivid musical snapshot of life during a tumultuous period, offering both a personal and universal meditation on modern-day existence. Based on Kahane’s fifth LP. 
   
 7:00 pm - Book of Travelers 
 Run Time:  70 minutes, no intermission 
   
 In Book of Travelers, Gabriel Kahane embarks on a journey across the United States, exploring the intersections of American identity and personal connection through the people he meets along the way. This powerful and emotional piece blends folk, classical, and pop influences to create a nuanced reflection on contemporary life in America. The work is a poignant and intimate exploration of what it means to traverse a country at a crossroads.

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: I AM | Camille A. Brown & Dancers
description:
Five-time Tony nominated choreographer and director Camille A. Brown deepens her explorations of Black joy in Camille A. Brown & Dancers’  I AM . With captivating live and original music,  I AM  launches new queries into the possibilities of imagination—and boldly investigates the future. Inspired by a narrative within HBO’s  Lovecraft Country  and the rhythms of the movie  Drumline , Brown’s 2025 New York Times Critics’ Pick breaks boundaries and “takes her signature interweaving of African diasporic dance forms to new heights.” —  The New York Times 
   
  To join us, be sure to pick up your free student ticket from the Alexander Kasser Theatre box office or our mobile box office in the student center lobby, Tuesdays and Thursdays, 11:30 AM to 2:00 PM, and show your student ID at the PEAK desk in the lobby when you arrive for a surprise gift from PEAK.

title: 2026 Black Alumni Advisory Council Black History Month Career Panel
description:
Heirs and Architects of a Great Legacy: Black History Month Alumni Event 
 In partnership with the African American Caucus and the African American Studies Department at Montclair State University, this special Black History Month event celebrates our history while providing tools to elevate your career. Join us for a unique opportunity to connect and network with accomplished alumni across diverse industries, united by the strength of family and community legacy. Hear from a panel of professionals who will share valuable insights to guide your career journey. Let their stories inspire and empower you to take your next step forward. 
 Event Details 🗓  Date:  Monday, February 16 ⏰  Time:  4 – 6 p.m. 📍  Location:  Feliciano School of Business, Room 140 💰  Cost:  FREE 📝  Registration:  Required (Sign up now!) 
   
 What’s in it for you? 
 
 Career Panel featuring alumni in the social services, business and the sciences 
 Networking with professionals who’ve been where you are, and who are now empowering others with their knowledge 
 Tips for launching your career and navigating your next steps 
 Direct access to alumni who are crushing it in their fields, showing the power of roots and wings in action 
 
   
 Meet the Panelists - TBD 
   
   
   
 What is BAAC? The Black Alumni Advisory Council (BAAC) connects Montclair State University alumni to current students to share knowledge, offer mentorship, and amplify social justice and inclusion in the community. We honor the strength of our shared roots while supporting the rise of empowered futures. 
 . 
 
   
 What is the African American Caucus of Montclair State University? 
 Awareness, Advocacy, and Change  The African American Caucus (AAC) of Montclair State University serves as a forum for discussion and advocacy regarding matters and issues important to faculty, staff, and students of African descent at Montclair State University. 
   
 What is African American Studies? 
 The African American Studies Minor is an interdisciplinary program.  Students examine the contributions people of African descent have made to human and world history. Courses critically analyze a wide range of philosophies, cultural experiences, social issues, leadership models and solutions to social problems. The program builds on the African American Studies scholar-activist tradition. Students explore education as a means not only for creating personal success but for developing stronger societies rooted in respect for diversity and human rights. 
   
 Got questions? Contact  The Office of Alumni Engagement at alumni@montclair.edu or 973-655-4141 
 This is your chance to level up your career game – don’t miss it!

title: Rent In Concert | Musical in Concert | Produced by AMP Worldwide
description:
Experience the iconic music of  RENT  like never before. In this sweeping symphonic concert produced by AMP Worldwide, a powerhouse ensemble of vocalists and instrumentalists brings Jonathan Larson’s groundbreaking rock musical to life in a sweeping symphonic concert. Featuring the full score—including “Seasons of Love,” “La Vie Bohème,” and “Take Me or Leave Me”—this electrifying performance celebrates the enduring spirit of love, loss, and chosen family. 
   
 Set in New York City’s East Village at the height of the HIV/AIDS crisis,  RENT  follows a group of young artists as they chase their dreams, navigate heartbreak, and fight to live—and love—fully in the moment. Winner of the Tony Award for Best Musical and the Pulitzer Prize for Drama,  RENT  remains a cultural touchstone with music that resonates across generations. 
   
 To join us, be sure to pick up your free student ticket from the Alexander Kasser Theatre box office or our mobile box office in the student center lobby, Tuesdays and Thursdays, 11:30 AM to 2:00 PM, and show your student ID at the PEAK desk in the lobby when you arrive for a surprise gift from PEAK.

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: Safe Space Training
description:
Our Safe Space Training is an intensive, interactive training that provides attendees with information and tools to combat homophobia, biphobia, transphobia, cissexism and heterosexism, on campus and beyond. Through interactive activities and discussion, participants will personally reflect on their own experiences to enhance their personal and professional development, provide further education, and finally, identify ways to create change on campus and beyond. 
 All sessions are three hours and are first-come, first-served. Pre-registration is required. Registrants are expected to attend the full session. Only individuals who have fully completed the Safe Space Program and have agreed to the expectations of its membership are able to display the sticker/button of our program. Refreshments are not provided; however, you are more than welcome to bring your lunch, coffee, snacks, etc.

title: Free Swim Lessons *Beginner*
description:
Brief Description:  
 Never swam before? No problem! These lessons will give you the important foundational skills in swimming and help you be more comfortable in the pool. Learn how to use proper breath control, float, and swim with a kickboard.

 Learning how to tread water

title: Clinical Psychology (MA) Virtual Information Session
description:
Transform Lives With A Career In Clinical Psychology 
 Montclair's Clinical Psychology program combines advanced education with practical experience. Whether you’re interested in working in private practice or research, we’ll walk you through the wide range of career paths available for clinical psychology graduates. We offer two  STEM-Designated  concentrations within our rigorous Master's program, tailored to your unique practice objectives: 
 
 Clinical Psychology, Child/Adolescent Psychology Concentration (MA) Students in the child/adolescent concentration learn about the unique psychological needs of children and adolescents, as well as developmental considerations in psychopathology, assessment, and treatment, including the role of family and social contexts. This concentration is designed to prepare students for MA-level clinical positions in mental health settings, particularly those that serve children and families.    
 Clinical Psychology, Forensic Psychology Concentration (MA) The Forensic Psychology concentration is designed to prepare students to offer master’s level clinical services to legal system-involved populations in settings that do not require licensure. Such settings include mental health and drug court settings, offender rehabilitation programs, child and family advocacy settings and bona fide public service agencies exempted by state boards of psychological examiners for non-doctoral providers. 
 
 Ready to learn more? Join us for a  virtual information session on March 9 at 5:30 PM (EST)  to explore Montclair's programs in Clinical Psychology and speak directly with our faculty.

title: Safe Space Training
description:
Our Safe Space Training is an intensive, interactive training that provides attendees with information and tools to combat homophobia, biphobia, transphobia, cissexism and heterosexism, on campus and beyond. Through interactive activities and discussion, participants will personally reflect on their own experiences to enhance their personal and professional development, provide further education, and finally, identify ways to create change on campus and beyond. 
 All sessions are three hours and are first-come, first-served. Pre-registration is required. Registrants are expected to attend the full session. Only individuals who have fully completed the Safe Space Program and have agreed to the expectations of its membership are able to display the sticker/button of our program. Refreshments are not provided; however, you are more than welcome to bring your lunch, coffee, snacks, etc.

description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
   
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Thursday: 4-5PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Higher Education (MA) Virtual Information Session
description:
Build your career in Higher Education    
 Whether you're already working in  higher ed  or looking to break into the field, our flexible program is designed to meet you where you are - and help you go even further. 
 We're hosting a  virtual information session on March 19  at 6:00 PM . This is a no-pressure, exploratory space to meet our team and determine if our program fits your goals. 
 Our coursework offers a broad focus on administration and leadership, preparing students for a variety of roles in higher education. The curriculum integrates organizational and social science perspectives and explores key administrative and programmatic issues.

title: Child Advocacy (MA) Alumni Perspectives: Advocating for Children in 2026
description:
Lead Change in Child Advocacy and Policy   When children and families face complex challenges, they need informed, compassionate professionals to stand up, speak out, and shape solutions. If you're ready to turn your commitment into action, we're here to help.  We're hosting a  virtual panel featuring alumni from our program on March 19 at 6:00 PM (EST) . This is a no-pressure, exploratory space to hear directly from professionals who were once in your shoes and determine if our program fits your goals. This session will cover the following programs:  
 
 Online Master of Arts in Child Advocacy and Policy 
 Child Advocacy (Certificate) – Online 
 
 Why Montclair?  Completing the certificate program allows you to transfer all 15 credits towards the Master of Arts in Child Advocacy, in accordance with all related graduate policy.

description:

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: Bench Press and Squat Competition
description:
Spring Strength Shadow! Welcome back to our annual Bench Press & Squat Competition. Come and test power and show your gains. Each event will feature 5 reps max. Whether you're chasing PRs or just want to flex for fun, this event is for you! Bring your friends and your lifting straps, and see who can lift their way to the top prize! 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Data: March 30th 
 Time: 3pm - 6pm 
 Student Recreation Center, Plae Room 
 
 How are results scored 
 
 Maximum 5 repetitions  
 1 attempt per lift after a warm up set 
 Scoring calculation: Weight lifted x repetitions divided by body weight  
 Final score will be a total of both lifts combined  
 
 Prizes :  
 
 Will be given to the top 3 winners  
 Tier 1: Beat Headphone ,  Fitness Watch ,  Air Fryer  $100-$200 
 Tier 2:  Massage Gun ,  Meal Prep Kit ,  Pilates Kit  $50-$100 
 Tier 3:  Foam Roller Set ,  Liquid IV ,  Owala Water Bottle  $20-$50 
 
 Free T-shirts - limited supply so show up early to claim one!

title: Free Swim Clinics
description:
Take your swimming even further! Do you have a specific skill you really want to work on but never had the chance to, or that you have been meaning to learn? title: 2010's DIY Nostalgia Night
description:
Throw it back to the days of glitter, bright colors, and the ultimate DIY era at 2010’s DIY Nostalgia Night! Recreate iconic favorites like Galaxy Slime, mixing shimmering glitter and bold hues for that classic space-vibe stretch. Build your own Galaxy Jar, layering dreamy colors and cotton clouds just like the crafts that once ruled YouTube. Then jump into the fun of Finger Loom Bands, making colorful bracelets just like the ones everyone traded and stacked in the early 2010s. 
   
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 No registration required 
 FREE for students with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 Where and when? 
 
 Tuesday, April 7 
 7pm-9pm, must be checked in by 8:30pm to participate 
 Student Recreation Center Lounge

title: Spring 2026 Part-time Job Fair
organization: The Office for Experiential Education and Career Connections
description:
The Spring Part-time Job Fair offers students the opportunity to meet with both on-campus and off-campus employers interested in hiring various positions. The Fair will be held in the Student Center Ballrooms from 1-3 p.m., on Wednesday, April 8.  
 
 
 More Information : 
 
 Bring plenty of copies of your resume 
 Students must bring their Montclair State University Student IDs 
 Registration is required through Handshake 
 The location is the Student Center Ballrooms

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: Free Swim Lessons *Beginner*
description:
Never swam before? No problem! These lessons will give you the important foundational skills in swimming and help you be more comfortable in the pool. Learn how to use proper breath control, float, and swim with a kickboard.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Being comfortable in the water 
 Learning how to float on your back and front 
 Learning how to kick off the wall with a kickboard 
 Introducing proper breath control in the water 
 Learning how to tread water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Froggy Kick) 
 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Wednesday: 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Free Swim Lessons *Intermediate*
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
   
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Wednesday: 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Safe Space Training
description:
Our Safe Space Training is an intensive, interactive training that provides attendees with information and tools to combat homophobia, biphobia, transphobia, cissexism and heterosexism, on campus and beyond. Through interactive activities and discussion, participants will personally reflect on their own experiences to enhance their personal and professional development, provide further education, and finally, identify ways to create change on campus and beyond. 
 All sessions are three hours and are first-come, first-served. Pre-registration is required. Registrants are expected to attend the full session. Only individuals who have fully completed the Safe Space Program and have agreed to the expectations of its membership are able to display the sticker/button of our program. Refreshments are not provided; however, you are more than welcome to bring your lunch, coffee, snacks, etc.

title: Denim Day Decorating
description: Show your support for Denim Day with a creative twist! Join us to decorate hats and tote bags using fabric markers, patches, and other fun materials. Craft something meaningful, stylish, and entirely your own—then wear or carry it proudly. All supplies provided!

title: Denim Day 2026: Mind the Gaps, Move Forward
description:
April is Sexual Assault Awareness Month, and together, we can break the silence.  The Montclair State University Police Department and the Office of Advocacy & Outreach are committed to fostering a campus where survivors feel heard, supported, and empowered.  It starts with believing. It starts with you.  By offering a safe and affirming response to those who disclose gender-based and sexual violence, we can create lasting change. Let’s stand together to end the cycle of silence—because  every voice matters, and every action counts. 
 Denim Day is recognized internationally as a day of action and awareness, encouraging people to wear denim to challenge victim-blaming and educate others about sexual violence.  This year, Denim Day falls on Wednesday, April 29, 2026. 
 The University Police and  Office of Advocacy & Outreach and the Office of Advocacy and Community Resilience , in partnership with over 30 campus and local community organizations, invites you to join us  from 9 a.m. to 12 p.m. at the Amphitheater  for a powerful awareness event honoring survivors and increasing awareness of available resources. 
 Despite the  gaps  that still exist in the criminal justice system, in resources, and in prevention education,  we will move forward together  as a community. As part of this commitment, we will walk  one mile around campus in solidarity with survivors.
